name: Red Light Therapy
summary: A non-invasive treatment that uses red and near-infrared wavelengths of light to stimulate cellular repair, reduce inflammation, and improve healing.
description: Red light therapy (RLT), also known as low-level laser therapy (LLLT) or photobiomodulation, uses specific wavelengths of red and near-infrared light to stimulate mitochondrial activity and cellular repair. It is a non-invasive approach that has been studied for pain reduction, wound healing, skin rejuvenation, and neurological recovery. Unlike UV light, red light does not damage skin cells, and the therapy is generally considered safe when administered properly.

treatment_duration: Multiple sessions, typically 2–5 times per week

contraindications: Direct eye exposure without protective eyewear
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe; mild temporary redness or warmth at the treatment site may occur. Avoid direct eye exposure without protection.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate for pain and wound healing; emerging for neurological applications.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Extensive preclinical and clinical research supports effects on mitochondrial function and healing.

sections.text: Red light therapy works by delivering low-level wavelengths of red and near-infrared light to tissues. These photons are absorbed by mitochondrial chromophores, especially cytochrome c oxidase, leading to increased ATP production, modulation of reactive oxygen species, and activation of transcription factors that promote cellular repair and anti-inflammatory effects.

sections.preparation: Clean the treatment area; protective eyewear may be used for facial sessions.
procedure: Patient positioned near LED panel or handheld red light device.
Device emits red and near-infrared light directly onto skin.
sections.total_treatment_time: Varies depending on condition; often several weeks to months.

items: LED panels or handheld red light devices

sections.treatment_phase: Application of red/infrared light to targeted area.
sections.post_session: Resume normal activity immediately; no downtime.
sections.home_practice: Home-use LED devices available for ongoing therapy.

immediate: Mild warmth or relaxation at treatment site

uncommon: Temporary headache or eye strain (if unprotected)

absolute: Direct irradiation of eyes without protection
special_considerations: Should not replace conventional cancer therapies

ideal_candidates: Patients with chronic pain or arthritis

studies: Clinical trials support effectiveness for chronic joint pain and arthritis.
Dermatology studies demonstrate improved collagen synthesis and skin texture.
Experimental studies suggest benefits in neuroprotection and TBI recovery.
sections.limitations: Varied protocols and device qualities; lack of standardization in dose and wavelength.

sections.insurance_coverage: Rarely covered; often considered wellness or cosmetic
sections.cost_effectiveness: Can be cost-effective with home devices, though clinical supervision may optimize outcomes.

sections.pediatric: Safe with proper dosing; avoid overuse.
sections.elderly: Well tolerated and effective for arthritis and wound healing.
sections.pregnancy: Limited data; use with caution and avoid abdominal application.
sections.comorbidities: Caution in patients with active cancers or severe photosensitivity.

items: Widely used in dermatology, physical therapy, and sports medicine.
Home-use devices allow for consistent application.
